The DOALOS participates in the inter-agency mechanism UN-Oceans, which seeks to enhance the coordination, coherence and effectiveness of competent organizations of the United Nations system and the International Seabed Authority on ocean issues (https://www.un.org/depts/los/coop_coor/un_oceans.htm). The DOALOS also liaises with other specialized agencies, regional and sub-regional organizations, non-governmental organizations, and academic institutions on matters related to ocean affairs and the law of the sea (https://www.un.org/oceancapacity/). DOALOS conducts consultations with regional intergovernmental organizations and others in Africa, Asia-Pacific, and Latin America/Caribben to gain insight in ongoing regional programmes and activities on ocean governance and to identify capacity-building needs and priorities in the region (https://www.un.org/oceancapacity/consultations).  The DOALOS facilitates the exchange of information and best practices among governments and other interested parties on issues under its consideration. For example, DOALOS works with the scientific community to support marine scientific research and with environmental sectors to address marine biodiversity conservation (https://www.un.org/depts/los/general_assembly/general_assembly.htm). DOALOS provides leadership and direction on matters critical to oceans and the law of the sea, shapes the ocean governance research agenda, sets norms and standards, articulates evidence-based policy options, provides technical support to countries, and monitors and assesses trends related to oceans and maritime affairs (https://www.un.org/ola/en/content/div-doalos). This structure facilitates information exchange and communication on actions addressing climate change and its impacts.

The ISA has established three principal organs: the Assembly, the Council, and the Secretariat, as well as two subsidiary organs: the Economic Planning Commission and the Legal and Technical Commission, to carry out its functions and responsibilities under the Convention (https://www.isa.org.jm/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/struct-funct.pdf). The ISA adopts and applies rules, regulations  and procedures for the management of activities in the Area, taking into account the protection of the marine environment, the equitable sharing of benefits, and the promotion of international cooperation ((https://www.isa.org.jm/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/isba_25_c_wp1-e_0.pdf)). The ISA also establishes a system of compensation or other measures of economic adjustment assistance for developing States that may be adversely affected by activities in the Area according to article 160 (10), Part XI of UNCLOS (https://www.un.org/depts/los/convention_agreements/texts/unclos/part11-4.htm). The ISA cooperates with other relevant international organizations and facilitates the exchange of scientific and technical information on activities in the Area (https://www.isa.org.jm/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/struct-funct.pdf).

Horizontal: Horizontal coordination within UN-Habitat involves collaboration with different sectors and stakeholders within the urban development and human settlements domain, such as national and local governments, civil society, private sector, academia, and other UN agencies to ensure sustainable urbanization. This coordination is presently guided by the UN-Habitat Strategic Plan for 2020-2023 (https://unhabitat.org/sites/default/files/documents/2019-09/strategic_plan_2020-2023.pdf). For example, UN-Habitat works with the housing sector to promote adequate and affordable housing for all (https://unhabitat.org/5-housing-and-slum-upgrading), with the transport sector to enhance urban mobility and accessibility (https://unhabitat.org/topic/mobility-and-transport), with the health sector to support urban health and well-being (https://unhabitat.org/topic/urban-health), or with the environment sector to strengthen climate action and improve urban environment (https://unhabitat.org/climate-action). Horizontal coordination within UN-Habitat can take various forms, such as: (1) Global flagship programmes, which are integrated and multisectoral programmes that aim to achieve impact at scale in the four domains of change of UN-Habitat, namely spatial inequality and poverty, shared prosperity, climate action and urban environment, and urban crisis prevention and response. They are designed and implemented in partnership with other sectors and stakeholders, such as UNDP, UNEP, UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, and others. Examples of global flagship programmes are the Global Public Space Programme (https://unhabitat.org/programme/global-public-space-programme) or the Participatory Slum Upgrading Programme (https://unhabitat.org/programme/the-participatory-slum-upgrading-programme-psup), (2) Interagency and multisectoral committees, networks, and platforms, which are mechanisms that facilitate coordination, information exchange, and joint action among different sectors and stakeholders on urban issues and policies. UN-Habitat participates in and leads several of these mechanisms, such as the UN Sustainable Development Group (https://unsdg.un.org/about), or the UN Task Team on the New Urban Agenda (https://habitat3.org/the-new-urban-agenda/preparatory-process/united-nations-task-team/), (3) Guidelines, standards, and tools for urban sector engagement through products that provide evidence-based guidance, technical norms, and practical solutions for urban sector engagement with other sectors and stakeholders, such as the International Guidelines on Urban and Territorial Planning (https://unhabitat.org/international-guidelines-on-urban-and-territorial-planning) or the City Prosperity Initiative (https://unhabitat.org/knowledge/city-prosperity-initiative), and (4) Advocacy and communication to raise awareness and mobilise support for urban issues and policies through activities that aim to influence and inform other sectors and stakeholders about the importance and potential of sustainable urbanization and human settlements, such as the World Habitat Day (https://unhabitat.org/world-habitat-day) or the World’s Cities Report (https://unhabitat.org/wcr/).

Institutions: Secretariat of the Basel, Rotterdam and Stockholm Conventions (BRS)
Horizontal:
Horizontal coordination within BRS Secretariat involves collaboration with different sectors and stakeholders within the chemicals and waste domain, such as governments, civil society, private sector, the scientific community, and other UN agencies to ensure that the sound management of chemicals and waste is achieved and that human health and the environment are protected from their adverse effects. This coordination is guided by the preambles and the objectives of the Basel, Rotterdam and Stockholm conventions (https://www.brsmeas.org/Secretariat/Overview/tabid/3609/language/en-US/Default.aspx). For example, the BRS Secretariat works with the health sector to prevent and reduce the exposure to hazardous chemicals and waste (such as mercury, lead, asbestos, and pesticides) and to promote the implementation of the health-related provisions of the conventions (https://www.brsmeas.org/Secretariat/Vision/Vision201819/tabid/7862/language/en-US/Default.aspx), with the agriculture sector to support the environmentally sound management of pesticides and other chemicals used in agriculture and to promote alternatives to hazardous pesticides (https://www.brsmeas.org/Implementation/ProgrammeofWork/SustainableDevelopmentGoals/Overview/tabid/8490/language/en-US/Default.aspx), the trade sector to facilitate the exchange of information and the prior informed consent procedure for certain hazardous chemicals and waste in international trade or with the climate change sector to address the linkages between chemicals (https://www.brsmeas.org/Implementation/ProgrammeofWork/SustainableDevelopmentGoals/Overview/tabid/8490/language/en-US/Default.aspx), waste and climate change and to promote low-carbon and circular economy approaches (https://www.brsmeas.org/Implementation/ProgrammeofWork/SustainableDevelopmentGoals/Overview/tabid/8490/language/en-US/Default.aspx). Horizontal coordination within BRS Secretariat can take various forms, such as: (1) Joint planning and implementation of programmes and projects with other sectors and stakeholders, such as the Special Programme on Institutional Strengthening for Chemicals and Waste Management or the Global Environment Facility (GEF) projects on persistent organic pollutants (POPs), mercury and integrated chemicals and waste management (https://www.brsmeas.org/Decisionmaking/COPsandExCOPs/20212022COPs/MeetingDocuments/tabid/8810/ctl/Download/mid/24689/language/en-GB/Default.aspx?id=111&ObjID=29473), (2) Participation in interagency and multisectoral committees, networks, and platforms, such as the Inter-Organization Programme for the Sound Management of Chemicals (IOMC) (https://www.brsmeas.org/Partners/IGOs/IOMC/tabid/4094/language/en-US/Default.aspx) or the Environmental Network for Optimizing Regulatory Compliance on Illegal Traffic (ENFORCE) (https://www.basel.int/Implementation/LegalMatters/IllegalTraffic/Meetings/ENFORCE8Brussels2024/tabid/9702/Default.aspx), (3) Development and dissemination of guidelines, standards, and tools for chemicals and waste sector engagement with other sectors and stakeholders, such as the technical guidelines for the environmentally sound management of waste or the guidance on best available techniques and best environmental practices for POPs 9https://www.brsmeas.org/Resources/Shared/scripts/appPubKit/docs/06a-StockholmConvention-GuidelinesBATBEP.English.pdf), (4) Advocacy and communication to raise awareness and mobilise support for chemicals and waste issues and policies among other sectors and stakeholders, such as the Triple COPs (https://enb.iisd.org/basel-rotterdam-stockholm-conventions-brs-cops-2023) or the online briefings and webinars. The BRS Secretariat provides leadership and direction on matters related to chemicals and waste management, shapes the policy agenda, sets norms and standards, articulates evidence-based policy options, provides technical support to parties, and monitors and assesses chemicals and waste trends (https://www.brsmeas.org/Secretariat/Overview/tabid/3609/language/en-US/Default.aspx).

Institutions: Secretariat of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES)
Horizontal:
Horizontal coordination within the CITES Secretariat involves collaboration with different organizations, instruments and processes that are relevant to the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity and wildlife trade, such as other biodiversity-related conventions, international organizations, enforcement agencies, scientific bodies, and civil society. This coordination is reflected in Goal 5 of the CITES Strategic Vision: 2021-2030 (https://cites.org/sites/default/files/reports/Implementation/E-SV-indicators.pdf), specifically under Indicators 5.14, and 5.15, as well as Objectives 5.2 and 5.3. For example, CITES works with the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) to align its objectives and actions with the post-2020 global biodiversity framework (https://cites.org/sites/default/files/documents/E-CoP19-Inf-11.pdf), with the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) to ensure the sustainable management of marine and tree species (https://cites.org/sites/default/files/eng/com/sc/62/E62-14-04-A1.pdf), with the World Health Organization (WHO) to address the links between wildlife trade and zoonotic diseases (https://cites.org/sites/default/files/documents/E-CoP19-23-02_0.pdf), or with the World Customs Organization (WCO) to enhance the capacity and effectiveness of customs officers in combating illegal wildlife trade (https://cites.org/sites/default/files/eng/disc/sec/CITES-WCO.pdf). Horizontal coordination within the CITES Secretariat can take various forms, such as: (1) Joint planning and implementation of programmes and projects with other organizations and processes, such as the International Consortium on Combating Wildlife Crime (ICCWC) (https://cites.org/eng/prog/iccwc.php) or the Joint CITES-CMS African Carnivores Initiative (https://cites.org/eng/node/55702), (2) Participation in interagency and multisectoral committees, groups, and platforms, such as the Biodiversity Liaison Group (BLG) (https://www.cbd.int/blg/) or the Environment Management Group (EMG) (https://unemg.org/), (3) Development and dissemination of guidelines, standards, and tools for CITES implementation and cooperation with other organizations and processes, such as the CITES guidelines for developing legislation (https://cites.org/sites/default/files/eng/prog/Legislation/guidelines_legislation.pdf) or the CITES Trade Database (https://trade.cites.org/), (4) Advocacy and communication to raise awareness and mobilise support for CITES issues and policies among other organizations and processes, such as the World Wildlife Day (https://www.wildlifeday.org/) or the CITES Newsletter (https://cites.org/eng/news/newsletter.php). The CITES Secretariat provides administrative and technical support to the Parties, facilitates the implementation and enforcement of the Convention, coordinates with other organizations and processes, and promotes the objectives and principles of CITES (https://cites.org/eng/disc/sec/index.php).

This coordination is guided by Article I of the UNU Charter, (https://unu.edu/sites/default/files/2022-12/UNU-Charter-2014.pdf), as well as by the UNU 2020-2024 Strategic Plan (https://i.unu.edu/media/unu.edu/attachment/100694/UNU-Strategic-Plan-2020-2024.pdf). For example, UNU consults with the education sector to provide topical, timely and relevant postgraduate training and degree programmes (https://unu.edu/learning), with the social sector to promote human rights and peace (https://unu.edu/topics/human-rights), with the economic sector to foster innovation and sustainable development (https://unu.edu/topics/innovation), and with the environmental sector to protect the environment and natural resources (https://unu.edu/topics/natural-resources). Horizontal coordination within UNU can take various forms, such as: (1) Joint research and training projects and programmes with other academic and research institutions, UN agencies, and other stakeholders, such as the UNU Institute for Integrated Management of Material Fluxes and of Resources (https://flores.unu.edu/en) or the UNU Institute for the Advanced Study of Sustainability (https://ias.unu.edu/en), (2) Participation in academic and policy networks, platforms, and partnerships, such as the Academic Council on the United Nations System (https://acuns.org) or the Sustainable Development Solutions Network (https://www.unsdsn.org), (3) Development and dissemination of publications, reports, and policy briefs for academic and policy audiences, such as the UNU Policy Brief Series (https://unu.edu/ias/unu-ias-policy-brief-series#:~:text=Our%20policy%20briefs%20present%20analysis,global%2C%20national%20and%20local%20levels.) or the UNU World Institute for Development Economics Research Working Paper Series (WIDER) (https://www.wider.unu.edu/publications), and (4) Advocacy and communication to raise awareness and mobilise support for the UNU's vision, mission, and activities among academic and policy communities, such as the UNU Conversation Series (https://unu.edu/events/unu-conversation-series) or the UNU Annual Report (https://unu.edu/about/annual-reports).

Horizontal: Horizontal coordination within the Ramsar Secretariat involves working with different partners and actors within the wetland domain, such as other global and regional conventions and agencies, national and local governments, civil society, private sector, and scientific and academic institutions to ensure that wetlands are conserved, wisely used, restored and valued by all. This coordination is supported by the Convention’s Strategic Plan 2016-2024 (https://www.ramsar.org/sites/default/files/documents/library/4th_strategic_plan_2016_2024_e.pdf). For example, the Ramsar Secretariat works with the biodiversity sector to support the implementation of other biodiversity-related conventions, such as the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) or the Convention on Migratory Species (CMS), with the water sector to promote the integration of wetlands into water resources management, such as the Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) or the Water Framework Directive (WFD), with the climate change sector to enhance the role of wetlands in climate change mitigation and adaptation, such as the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) or the Paris Agreement, or with the disaster risk reduction sector to highlight the importance of wetlands in reducing disaster risks, such as the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction or the Hyogo Framework for Action (https://www.ramsar.org/about/partnerships/partnerships-other-conventions). Horizontal coordination within the Ramsar Secretariat can take various forms, such as: (1) Joint planning and implementation of programmes and projects with other partners and actors, such as the Ramsar Regional Initiatives (https://www.ramsar.org/activity/ramsar-regional-initiatives) or the Wetlands for the Future Fund (https://www.ramsar.org/wetlands-future), (2) Participation in intergovernmental and multisectoral committees, networks, and platforms, such as the Biodiversity Liaison Group (https://www.cbd.int/blg/) or the Global Partnership for Plant Conservation (https://www.plants2020.net/), (3) Development and dissemination of guidelines, standards, and tools for wetland sector engagement with other partners and actors, such as the Ramsar Handbooks (https://www.ramsar.org/sites/default/files/documents/pdf/lib/hbk4-18.pdf) or the Ramsar Advisory Missions (https://www.ramsar.org/activity/ramsar-advisory-missions), and (4) Advocacy and communication to raise awareness and mobilise support for wetland issues and policies among other partners and actors, such as the World Wetlands Day (https://www.worldwetlandsday.org/) or the Ramsar Awards (https://www.ramsar.org/our-work/activities/ramsar-awards).

Horizontal: Horizontal coordination within the Minamata Convention Secretariat involves collaboration with different sectors and stakeholders within the mercury domain, such as governments, civil society, private sector, the scientific community, and other UN agencies to protect human health and the environment from the adverse effects of mercury. This coordination is guided by Article 24 of the Minamata Convention on Mercury (https://minamataconvention.org/sites/default/files/2021-06/Minamata-Convention-booklet-Sep2019-EN.pdf) as part of the functions of the Secretariat. For example, the Secretariat works with the health sector to support the phase-out of mercury in medical devices and dental amalgam (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/mercury-and-health#:~:text=A%20significant%20example%20of%20mercury,included%20high%20concentrations%20of%20methylmercury.), with the mining sector to promote the reduction and elimination of mercury use in artisanal and small-scale gold mining (https://2009-2017.state.gov/e/oes/eqt/chemicalpollution/mercury/245187.htm), with the waste sector to ensure the environmentally sound management and transportation of mercury wastes (https://minamataconvention.org/sites/default/files/documents/submission_from_government/%28JPN%29Article11.pdf), or with the trade sector to regulate the import and export of mercury and mercury compounds (https://minamataconvention.org/en/news/minamata-online-article-3-trade-mercury). Horizontal coordination within the Minamata Convention Secretariat can take various forms, such as: (1) Joint planning and implementation of programmes and projects with other sectors and stakeholders, such as the Global Environment Facility (https://www.thegef.org/topics/chemicals-and-waste) or the Special Programme on Institutional Strengthening (https://www.unep.org/explore-topics/chemicals-waste/what-we-do/special-programme/goal-special-programme), (2) Participation in interagency and multisectoral committees, networks, and platforms, such as the Inter-Organization Programme for the Sound Management of Chemicals (https://partnership.who.int/iomc) or the Global Mercury Partnership (https://minamataconvention.org/en/about/partners/global-mercury-partnership#:~:text=Initiated%20in%202005%20by%20a,legally%2Dbinding%20instrument%20on%20mercury.), (3) Development and dissemination of guidelines, standards, and tools for mercury sector engagement with other sectors and stakeholders, such as the Minamata Initial Assessments (https://minamataconvention.org/en/parties/minamata-initial-assessments) or the Mercury Inventory Toolkit (https://www.unep.org/topics/chemicals-and-pollution-action/pollution-and-health/heavy-metals/mercury/mercury-inventory), and (4) Advocacy and communication to raise awareness and mobilise support for mercury issues and policies among other sectors and stakeholders, such as the International Conference on Mercury as a Global Pollutant (https://minamataconvention.org/en/news/icmgp-2022-reducing-mercury-emissions-achieve-greener-world) or the Minamata Online E-Learning Platform (https://minamataconvention.org/en/resources/e-learning).

Institutions: United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA)
Horizontal: Horizontal coordination within UNOOSA involves collaboration with different sectors and stakeholders within the space domain, including its Member States, United Nations entities, intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations, and industry and private sector entities, to promote and facilitate the peaceful uses of outer space and the use of space science and technology for sustainable development. This coordination is guided by the resolutions and decisions of the General Assembly and the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (COPUOS) (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/documents-and-resolutions/search.jspx?view=documents&f=oosaDocument.doctags.doctag_s%3ACOPUOSRDOCS), as well as the “Space2030” Agenda and implementation plan (https://www.unoosa.org/res/oosadoc/data/documents/2024/stspace/stspace88_0_html/st_space-088E.pdf). For example, UNOOSA works with the disaster management sector to provide access to space-based information and services for disaster risk reduction and emergency response through the UN-SPIDER programme (https://www.un-spider.org/), with the health sector to strengthen space cooperation for global health (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/psa/globalhealth/index.html), with the education sector to enhance capacity-building, education and training in space science and applications, as well as space law and policy, through the regional centres for space science and technology education, affiliated to the United Nations (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/psa/regional-centres/index.html), or with the environment sector to support the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the Sendai Framework by using space-based data and applications (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/topics/space-and-climate-change.html). Horizontal coordination within UNOOSA can take various forms, such as: (1) Joint planning and implementation of programmes and projects with other sectors and stakeholders, such as the Access to Space for All initiative (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/access2space4all/index.html) or the Space for Women project (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/topics/spaceforwomen/index.html), (2) Participation in interagency and multisectoral committees, networks, and platforms, such as the Inter-Agency Meeting on Outer Space Activities (UN-Space) (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/un-space/iam.html) or the International Committee on Global Navigation Satellite Systems (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/icg/icg.html), (3) Development and dissemination of guidelines, standards, and tools for space sector engagement with other sectors and stakeholders, such as the United Nations treaties and principles on outer space (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/spacelaw/treaties.html) or the guidelines for the long-term sustainability of outer space activities (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/topics/long-term-sustainability-of-outer-space-activities.html), and (4) Advocacy and communication to raise awareness and mobilise support for space issues and policies among other sectors and stakeholders, such as the World Space Week (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/outreach/events/wsw/index.html) or the World Space Forums (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/world-space-forum/WSF-main-page.html). UNOOSA provides leadership and direction on matters related to the peaceful uses of outer space and the use of space science and technology for sustainable development, shapes the space agenda, sets norms and standards, articulates evidence-based policy options, provides technical support to countries, and monitors and assesses space trends (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/aboutus/structure.html).

Institutions: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)
Horizontal: Horizontal coordination within UNODC involves collaboration with different sectors and stakeholders within the drug, crime, corruption and terrorism domains, such as governments, civil society, private sector, academia, and other UN entities to ensure that the world is safer from these threats and that human rights, development and the rule of law are upheld in all activities and policies. This coordination is guided by the UNODC Strategy 2021-2025 (https://www.unodc.org/documents/Advocacy-Section/UNODC-Strategy-WEB.pdf). For example, UNODC works with the health sector to address the world drug problem and provide prevention and treatment services (https://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/drug-prevention-and-treatment/index.html), with the justice sector to prevent and counter organized crime and terrorism and strengthen criminal justice systems (https://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/organized-crime/index.html, https://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/terrorism/index.html, https://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/justice-and-prison-reform/index.html), with the environment sector to combat crimes that affect the environment and biodiversity (https://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/wildlife-and-forest-crime/index.html), or with the education sector to promote a culture of lawfulness and prevent violence and crime among youth (https://www.unodc.org/e4j/). Horizontal coordination within UNODC can take various forms, such as: (1) Joint planning and implementation of programmes and projects with other sectors and stakeholders, such as the Global Programme for Combating Wildlife and Forest Crime (https://www.unodc.org/documents/Wildlife/Annual_Report_GPWLFC2021.pdf) or the Global Maritime Crime Programme (https://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/piracy/index.html), (2) Participation in interagency and multisectoral committees, networks, and platforms, such as the Inter-Agency Coordination Group against Trafficking in Persons (https://icat.un.org/) or the United Nations Global Counter-Terrorism Coordination Compact (https://www.un.org/counterterrorism/global-ct-compact), (3) Development and dissemination of guidelines, standards, and tools for drug, crime, corruption and terrorism sector engagement with other sectors and stakeholders, such as the International Standards for the Treatment of Drug Use Disorders (https://www.unodc.org/documents/drug-prevention-and-treatment/UNODC-WHO_International_Standards_Treatment_Drug_Use_Disorders_April_2020.pdf) or the Global Judicial Integrity Network (https://www.unodc.org/ji/en/index.html), and (4) Advocacy and communication to raise awareness and mobilise support for drug, crime, corruption and terrorism issues and policies among other sectors and stakeholders, such as the World Drug Report (https://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/data-and-analysis/world-drug-report-2023.html) or the Education for Justice initiative (https://www.unodc.org/e4j/en/index.html).
